diagnoses: Drug Reactions (e.g., Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms [DRESS] Syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's more common in children. The symptoms you've described are characteristic, especially when they appear together.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease resulting from a group A streptococcus infection, known for a distinctive rash, fever, and other symptoms you mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: A highly contagious viral infection causing fever, conjunctivitis, cough, and a characteristic rash.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This condition can lead to a variety of symptoms, including anemia, cracking of lips, and a weakened immune system, which might result in more infections causing fever and rashes.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)
diagnoses.description: A mild viral infection causing fever, a distinctive face rash (slapped cheek appearance), and a maculopapular rash on the body.

diagnoses.name: Sickle Cell Disease
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect hemoglobin, the molecule in red blood cells that delivers oxygen to cells throughout the body. It can cause anemia and increase susceptibility to infections, potentially explaining the fever and rash.

diagnoses.name: Glucagonoma
diagnoses.description: A rare type of tumor in the pancreas that can cause a characteristic rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), anemia, and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare but serious disorder that affects the skin and mucous membranes, potentially leading to a severe rash, fever, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including skin, joints, and internal organs. The symptoms you described can occur in SLE.

diagnoses.name: Acute HIV Infection
diagnoses.description: The initial period following the contraction of HIV can present with fever, rash, and other flu-like symptoms.

diagnoses: Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Reactive lymphadenopathy due to viral or bacterial infection

Schizophrenia (in the context of understanding differential diagnoses with psychosis)

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints, leading to pain, swelling, and potential loss of function. It can also cause systemic symptoms, including fever, and has been associated with pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect nearly any part of the body, notably the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. It can cause arthropathy, synovitis, acute pericarditis, fever, and a characteristic butterfly facial rash.

diagnoses.name: Adult-onset Still's disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inflammatory disorder characterized by fever, arthritis, and a salmon-colored rash. It may also cause acute pericarditis and dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Skin discoloration and joint pain are common symptoms, along with potential heart complications such as pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Reactive arthritis
diagnoses.description: A condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body (cross-reactivity). It can lead to joint pain and swelling, skin problems, and occasionally heart inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory type of arthritis that affects some people with psoriasis. It can cause swelling, pain in joints (arthropathy), and skin lesions.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition characterized by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. While primarily affecting skin and muscles, it can also lead to joint issues and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed connective tissue disease
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that may have signs and symptoms of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including joint pain, skin changes, and muscle weakness, as well as potential heart involvement.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium spread by ticks. Its symptoms may include fever, headache, fatigue, and a characteristic skin rash called erythema migrans. It can progress to affect the joints, heart, and nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Infectious endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the inner lining of your heart chambers and heart valves (endocardium). It can produce fever, heart murmurs, petechiae, and other systemic symptoms due to the spread of infection through the bloodstream.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as nephritis, autoimmune hemolysis, alopecia, and fever. Follicular hyperkeratosis can also occur in lupus patients, albeit less commonly.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for its muscle and skin manifestations, dermatomyositis can sometimes present with features such as alopecia, fever, and, less commonly, nephritis. Autoimmune hemolysis and follicular hyperkeratosis are not hallmark symptoms but can occur in autoimmune disorders.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting the joints, this systemic autoimmune condition can manifest with fever and autoimmune hemolysis. Follicular hyperkeratosis, alopecia, and nephritis are less common but possible due to systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: This disease shows overlap symptoms of various connective tissue diseases, including SLE, which shares many symptoms listed, such as nephritis and autoimmune hemolysis. Alopecia and fever are also common.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Known for dry eyes and mouth, it can also have systemic manifestations including nephritis and, albeit rarely, autoimmune hemolysis. Alopecia and fever can occur as well.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.rationale: This is a systemic vasculitis that can affect various organs, including the kidneys (nephritis) and skin, potentially leading to symptoms like fever. Alopecia and autoimmune hemolysis are less typical but possible.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily a skin condition that can cause follicular hyperkeratosis. Systemic symptoms such as fever are possible, especially in psoriatic arthritis. Nephritis, alopecia, and autoimmune hemolysis are less common.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
diagnoses.rationale: A condition with potential skin and hair involvement, leading to alopecia and follicular hyperkeratosis. Less commonly associated with nephritis and autoimmune phenomena.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: A general term for conditions causing inflammation of blood vessels, which can lead to widespread organ involvement including the kidneys (nephritis) and potentially inducing fever. Autoimmune hemolysis, alopecia, and follicular hyperkeratosis are less directly associated but can be seen in systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Pemphigus Foliaceus
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune blistering disorder that can result in skin findings such as follicular hyperkeratosis. While nephritis is not a common manifestation, systemic symptoms like fever are possible. Alopecia can occur around lesion sites.

diagnoses: Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can manifest in a wide range of symptoms including pleural effusion, acute pericarditis, and potentially lead to central nervous system involvement causing delirium. Arthritis or synovitis is a common symptom, and skin manifestations such as follicular hyperkeratosis may occur.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: RA can cause synovitis as a primary symptom, and in severe cases, it can be associated with pleural effusions and pericarditis. While less common, skin manifestations and systemic symptoms could potentially lead to delirium especially in the context of severe disease or complications.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis is known for affecting multiple organ systems - including the skin (leading to lesions that could resemble follicular hyperkeratosis), lungs (pleural effusion), heart (acute pericarditis), and potentially the nervous system, which could explain delirium. Joint involvement can cause synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: This inflammatory disease is known for affecting skin (which can cause symptoms like follicular hyperkeratosis) and muscles, and it can have pulmonary manifestations (pleural effusion). While less common, it can involve the heart, leading to acute pericarditis, and systemic inflammation could potentially lead to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD may present with features of several autoimmune diseases including lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It can lead to synovitis, skin manifestations like follicular hyperkeratosis, pleural effusion, and acute pericarditis. Neurological involvement, although less common, could account for delirium.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can lead to a wide array of symptoms, including pericarditis, pleural effusion, and even skin manifestations. Neurological involvement could cause delirium, and reactive arthritis might manifest as synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, Lyme disease can present with arthritis (synovitis), neurological symptoms (potentially delirium in late-stage neuroborreliosis), and less commonly, cardiac involvement such as pericarditis. Skin manifestations in Lyme disease are more commonly erythema migrans but can affect the skin in diverse ways.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis (TB)
diagnoses.rationale: TB can cause pleurisy leading to pleural effusion, pericarditis, and potentially impact the skin. Joint involvement (tuberculous arthritis) could present as synovitis, and TB meningitis could manifest as delirium.

diagnoses.name: Whipple's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This rare bacterial infection can affect many parts of the body, including the joints (synovitis), the nervous system (delirium), and potentially the heart (pericarditis). Skin manifestations are less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Scurvy
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, scurvy can lead to symptoms that may mimic some of these conditions, such as follicular hyperkeratosis and potentially joint pain (synovitis-like symptoms). While pleural effusion, pericarditis, and delirium are far less common, overall malnutrition could contribute to a broad symptomatology.

diagnoses: Viral systemic infections (e.g., dengue fever, chikungunya)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own tissues, affecting the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands responsible for keeping the eyes, mouth, and other parts of the body moist and lubricated.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, most commonly the lungs and lymph glands.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome - a disease that attacks the body’s immune system, leading to eventual severe immune compromise.

diagnoses.name: Hypersensitivity Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that causes changes in the blood vessel walls.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Renal Failure
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys do not work effectively.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.description: A condition in which an abnormal protein, amyloid, builds up in the organs and interferes with their normal function.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A serious blood vessel disease where small and medium-sized arteries become swollen and damaged.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, part of the body’s immune system.

diagnoses: Chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus)
Primary disorders of the autonomic nervous system (e.g., pure autonomic failure, multiple system atrophy)
Endocrine disorders (e.g., thyroid disorders, adrenal insufficiency)
Sleep disorders (e.g., obstructive sleep apnea, insomnia)
Sleep Disorder related to another mental disorder

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Hypoferritinemia is a hallmark of iron deficiency, which can lead to anemia and subsequently to symptoms like bone pain and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML)
diagnoses.reasoning: Monocytosis (increased monocytes) can be a key feature, along with hypoferritinemia due to chronic disease. CMML can cause systemic symptoms like nausea and bone pain.

diagnoses.name: Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS)
diagnoses.reasoning: These syndromes may present with monocytosis and can lead to bone marrow failure with symptoms such as bone pain, and hypoferritinemia.

diagnoses.name: Renal insufficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause bone pain due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, hypoferritinemia due to chronic disease, and blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Multiple myeloma
diagnoses.reasoning: A blood cancer that causes bone pain, and can be associated with anemia (hypoferritinemia) and systemic symptoms like nausea.

diagnoses.name: Primary myelofibrosis
diagnoses.reasoning: This blood disorder can cause bone pain, anemia, monocytosis, and systemic symptoms such as nausea.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause systemic inflammation resulting in bone pain, blood pressure lability, and potentially hypoferritinemia due to chronic disease.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Typically associated with high ferritin levels, yet patients might present with hypoferritinemia if there’s concurrent chronic inflammation, causing symptoms like joint pain or bone pain.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D deficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to bone pain. While not directly causing hypoferritinemia, it may coincide with nutritional deficiencies contributing to other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.reasoning: A systemic inflammatory disease that can cause bone pain, blood pressure lability due to cardiovascular effects, and could be associated with anemia of chronic disease (hypoferritinemia) and monocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Emotional stress, such as that caused by anxiety disorders, can trigger takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as broken heart syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.reason: Commonly presents with symptoms such as post-nasal drip, which can also lead to wheezing due to throat irritation.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.reason: May cause post-nasal drip and dysgeusia due to acid reflux, and indirectly lead to or aggravate wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Respiratory Tract Infections
diagnoses.reason: Can cause wheezing and post-nasal drip, and some infections may temporarily alter taste (dysgeusia).

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.reason: Primarily characterized by wheezing. The condition could be exacerbated by stress, contributing to takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.reason: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs, presenting symptoms such as wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Rhinosinusitis
diagnoses.reason: Inflammation of the sinuses leading to symptoms such as post-nasal drip, and may also cause or exacerbate wheezing due to mucus.

diagnoses.name: Environmental Allergies
diagnoses.reason: Exposure to allergens can lead to an allergic reaction presenting symptoms such as wheezing and post-nasal drip.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Side Effects
diagnoses.reason: Some medications can cause side effects including dysgeusia, wheezing, and exacerbation of existing conditions like takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Stress or emotional factors associated with psychological disorders can precipitate takotsubo cardiomyopathy and physical sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic Dysregulation
diagnoses.description: This encompasses dysfunctions of the autonomic nervous system, including POTS, and could lead to or contribute to symptoms like hyperactivity and pseudoseizures.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: MCAS can cause a wide range of symptoms, including angioedema, sinusitis, and contribute to autonomic dysregulation.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: CFS can present with a range of symptoms including postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome and hyperactivity due to nervous system arousal.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes (EDS)
diagnoses.description: EDS is a connective tissue disorder that can present with dysautonomia, including POTS, and predisposes individuals to sinusitis due to its effect on connective tissues.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Chemical Sensitivity (MCS)
diagnoses.description: MCS can lead to various symptoms, including those affecting the nervous system like hyperactivity and pseudoseizures, and also sinusitis due to environmental irritants.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: This could explain the sinusitis and possibly the angioedema if the individual is experiencing severe allergies.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Non-epileptic Seizures (PNES)
diagnoses.description: Also known as pseudoseizures, this diagnosis could be considered given the symptom, and can co-occur with other disorders like POTS.

diagnoses.name: Somatization Disorder
diagnoses.description: This mental disorder can manifest with a variety of physical symptoms, including those listed, without a clear medical cause.

diagnoses.name: Immune Dysregulation
diagnoses.description: An overarching issue with the immune system could potentially cause symptoms like angioedema and sinusitis.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: Anxiety can exacerbate or mimic symptoms of POTS and could also lead to or aggravate conditions like hyperactivity and pseudoseizures.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys don't work as well as they should.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition where the thyroid gland is overactive and produces too much thyroid hormone.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition where ulcers form on the lining of the stomach or the first part of the small intestine.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism, where the immune system mistakenly attacks the thyroid gland.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Nephropathy
diagnoses.description: Kidney damage that results from having diabetes.

diagnoses.name: Hypokalemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by low potassium levels in the blood, which can cause weakness, muscle cramps, and arrhythmias.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure, a common issue in those with chronic kidney disease and can also be related to hyperthyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a lack of healthy red blood cells, which can occur in chronic kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where stomach acid comes up from the stomach into the esophagus, which can also lead to ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that causes muscle weakness. While not directly associated with hyperthyroidism, kidney disease, or ulcers, some symptoms may overlap, such as episodic weakness.

diagnoses: Blepharospasm may indicate conditions affecting the eye or neurological disorders.
Striae, commonly known as stretch marks, can result from conditions causing skin stretching or hormonal changes.
Irritated eyes could be symptomatic of allergies, dry eye syndrome, or infections like conjunctivitis.
Laryngitis, the inflammation of the voice box, may result from viral infections, vocal strain, or allergies.
Mood lability could be a sign of psychiatric conditions, hormonal imbalances, or neurological disorders.
Autoimmune disorders, as certain conditions can involve immune system dysfunction affecting multiple body systems.
Thyroid disorders, seeing that both mood lability and skin changes can be symptoms.
Contact dermatitis, considering skin and eye irritation, which might be triggered by an allergen or irritant.
Neurological conditions, like Parkinson's disease or Tourette syndrome, could explain blepharospasm allied with mood lability.
Addison's disease, given that striae, mood changes, and skin irritation could be symptoms of this hormonal disorder.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder causing mouth ulcers, genital ulcers, skin problems, and eye inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body, causing joint pain, eye inflammation, and urinary problems.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to various body systems, including the joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, which can also cause vaginal dryness and increase the risk of dental and genital ulcers.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A virus that attacks the immune system, increasing susceptibility to infections and can lead to symptoms such as mouth ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Candidiasis
diagnoses.description: A fungal infection caused by yeasts that belong to the genus Candida, leading to symptoms such as vaginitis.

diagnoses.name: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that can cause sores on the genitals and/or mouth, as well as affecting the skin and other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a lack of enough iron in the body, leading to symptoms such as ulcers in the mouth and an altered sense of taste (dysgeusia).

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This condition can lead to mouth ulcers, altered taste sensation (dysgeusia), and increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Zinc is essential for immune system function, and deficiency can lead to symptoms including increased susceptibility to infections, hyperactivity, and taste alterations (dysgeusia).

diagnoses: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Lung

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer originating from white blood cells called lymphocytes, characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. Symptoms go beyond those listed and can include fever, weight loss, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A diverse group of blood cancers that include any kind of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas. Symptoms can vary but often include enlarged lymph nodes, fever, belly pain, chest pain, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can present with sweats, fatigue, and a feeling of fullness after eating only a small amount.

diagnoses.name: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that affects white blood cells. Symptoms include fever, frequent infections, bleeding or bruising easily, fatigue, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A rare blood disorder in which your bone marrow makes too many red blood cells. Can cause headaches, dizziness, and itchiness after bathing in warm water. It may present with an enlarged spleen and a ruddy complexion.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it is a contagious disease often called mono or 'the kissing disease.' Symptoms include fatigue, sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A contagious infection caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs but can also affect lymph nodes, causing a persistent cough, night sweats, and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A stage of the sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. Symptoms can include skin rash, fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include fatigue, fever, swollen lymph nodes, and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Castleman Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that involves an overgrowth of cells in your body's lymph nodes. Symptoms vary depending on the type of Castleman disease, but they may include fever, night sweats, and enlarged lymph nodes.

An endocrine disorder where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone. Symptoms can include increased appetite and cognitive dysfunction, and mood changes. Hypothyroidism can also lead to elevated cholesterol levels, potentially exacerbating atherosclerosis.

A condition resulting from chronic exposure to high levels of cortisol. Patients may experience increased appetite, mood lability, and cognitive impairments. Cushing's Syndrome may also contribute to atherosclerosis through metabolic changes.

A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar levels over a prolonged period. It can cause increased appetite and cognitive dysfunction. Diabetes is a risk factor for atherosclerosis due to the damage high glucose levels can inflict on blood vessels.

An endocrine disorder where the thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone, leading to increased appetite and cognitive problems. Mood lability can also occur. While not directly causing atherosclerosis, hyperthyroidism can influence cardiovascular risk factors.

A rare, genetic disorder that causes severe swelling, typically in limbs, face, and the gastrointestinal tract. While it directly doesn't explain atherosclerosis, cognitive dysfunction, or appetite changes, it fits the angioedema symptom and can have varied systemic impacts.
Similar to hereditary angioedema, but caused by factors other than genetics, such as certain medications or other medical conditions. This diagnosis would mainly address the angioedema symptom.

A mood disorder that causes persistent feelings of sadness and loss of interest. It can lead to changes in appetite and cognitive function, as well as mood lability. Depression does not directly cause atherosclerosis but can contribute to risk factors for cardiovascular disease.

A mental health condition that causes extreme mood swings including emotional highs (mania or hypomania) and lows (depression). This condition may explain mood lability, cognitive dysfunction, and changes in appetite.
A cluster of conditions that occur together, increasing your risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. These conditions can include increased appetite and atherosclerosis.

A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have enlarged ovaries that contain small collections of fluid. It can cause increased appetite and is associated with metabolic syndrome, hence indirectly related to atherosclerosis.

diagnoses: Vitamin Deficiencies (e.g., Vitamin B12, Vitamin D)
Hearing loss associated with certain syndromes
Connective tissue disease (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)
Vitamin Deficiencies (e.g., Vitamin D, Vitamin B12)
Primary Sleep Disorders (e.g., Insomnia, Sleep Apnea)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Allergic Rhinitis (for sneezing, if combined with a gastrointestinal virus)
Seasonal influenza (if sneezing is more related to a flu-like syndrome)
Giardiasis (if the source is contaminated water or food)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) exacerbation with allergic component
Toxic exposure (e.g., insect sting, food allergies)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: Migraine headaches can sometimes cause weakness and are often associated with sensory disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.details: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the brain and spinal cord, causing weakness, coordination, balance difficulties, and in some cases, hearing problems.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: Growths in the brain can pressure hearing structures and nerves, causing loss of hearing and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Schwannoma
diagnoses.details: Also known as acoustic neuroma, this is a benign tumor on the vestibulocochlear nerve leading to hearing loss and balance problems.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: A stroke can affect areas of the brain responsible for hearing and balance, causing hearing loss and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Ototoxic Medication Exposure
diagnoses.details: Certain medications can damage the inner ear, leading to hearing loss, and other symptoms might include neurologic symptoms like weakness and headaches in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.details: A tick-borne illness that can cause a wide range of symptoms including headaches, facial palsy leading to weakness, and hearing loss in advanced stages.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease
diagnoses.details: An immune system malfunction that specifically targets the inner ear, resulting in progressive hearing loss and potentially other neurologic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.details: An inflammation of the arteries in and around the scalp, causing severe headaches, jaw pain, and can lead to sudden, unilateral hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: Migraine headaches can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head. It's often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound. Migraine attacks can cause significant pain for hours to days and can be so severe that the pain is disabling.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms include numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, typically on one side of your body at a time, or the legs and trunk.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms include trouble speaking and understanding what others are saying, paralysis or numbness of the face, arm or leg.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.details: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It's caused by a decrease in blood supply to part of the brain, which may result in a sudden but temporary weakness or numbness in the arms, legs, or face, especially on one side of the body, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Cervical Spondylosis
diagnoses.details: This condition affects the cervical spine in the neck and can lead to numbness and weakness in the hands and arms, along with headaches, especially in the back of the head. It is caused by wear and tear of the cartilage and bones of the neck.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.details: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. It affects the legs and feet first, followed by the arms and hands, often causing weakness, numbness, and pain.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain or close to your brain. Symptoms vary widely and depend on the brain tumor's size, location, and rate of growth. Common symptoms include new onset or change in pattern of headaches, headaches that gradually become more frequent and more severe, and numbness or weakness in one part of the body.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.details: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. It can cause fatigue and weakness. In some cases, headaches might also occur as a symptom.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.details: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Patients may also experience headaches and numbness or tingling in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.details: This deficiency can cause various neurological problems, including numbness and tingling in the hands and feet, muscle weakness, and loss of reflexes. It may also lead to memory loss, confusion, and, in severe cases, depression or mania. Headaches are another symptom that can be associated with the deficiency.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms like headache, aphasia, and sometimes nausea.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent headaches that are moderate to severe and often accompanied by nausea and sensitivity to light or sound.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: Any intracranial tumor caused by abnormal and uncontrolled cell division, presenting symptoms such as headaches, nausea, and language disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it's a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, such as headache and difficulty speaking, but usually lasting only a few minutes to hours.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges, causing severe headache, nausea, and sometimes problems with speech.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain tissue, often causing flu-like symptoms, severe headaches, aphasia, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness.

diagnoses.name: Brain abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection, causing headaches, nausea, and in advanced cases, aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system), where the immune system attacks the protective myelin sheath, leading to symptoms including speech difficulties and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Primary CNS vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessel walls in the brain or spine, which can lead to headaches, aphasia, and other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around your nerve fibers, leading to delayed response or permanent nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines that are preceded or accompanied by sensory warning signs or symptoms, such as flashes of light, blind spots, or tingling in your hand or face.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from receiving oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die within minutes.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some are noncancerous (benign), and some are cancerous (malignant). Symptoms depend on the size, location, and rate of growth.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to muscle weakness and even paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from a blockage or damage in the vertebral arteries or veins, leading to reduced blood flow to the back part of the brain. Symptoms can include dizziness, double vision, slurred speech, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Symptoms can include fatigue, fever, skin rashes, and facial paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
diagnoses.description: A disorder arising from a problem in the inner ear. Symptoms are repeated episodes of positional vertigo, a spinning sensation caused by changes in the position of the head.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. In some cases, migraines are preceded by sensory disturbances called auras, which can include visual phenomena such as scintillations.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing episodes of spinning vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus (ringing in the ear), and a feeling of fullness or pressure in the ear. These symptoms can lead to fatigue and a sense of weakness due to the body's response to vertigo and imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Tension-type Headaches
diagnoses.description: The most common type of primary headache, characterized by a constant pressure or ache around the head, particularly at the temples or back of the head and neck. Not usually associated with symptoms such as nausea or vomiting, but chronic tension headaches can lead to fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuronitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the vestibular nerve causing severe, sudden vertigo, which can lead to nausea, vomiting, and imbalance. This condition might also cause a person to experience tinnitus as a side effect of the vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Any intracranial tumor can cause headache, weakness, and tinnitus, depending on its location and size. Tumors may also interfere with normal brain function, leading to a multitude of symptoms, including scintillating scotoma as part of a symptom complex.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. It can lead to fatigue, weakness, visual disturbances (including scintillations), and difficulty coordinating movements. Tinnitus is less common but can occur in some individuals.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, causing fatigue and weakness. Headache and tinnitus can also occur when anemia is severe.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of blood vessels, usually in the temples, causing a throbbing headache, scalp tenderness, jaw pain, and sometimes symptoms like transient vision loss (which can be confused with scintillations). Fatigue and weakness are also common.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A noncancerous tumor on the nerve that connects the ear to the brain. It can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, balance disorders, and headaches as it grows.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure can lead to headache, tinnitus, and a sense of weakness or fatigue. It's often called the 'silent killer' because it rarely causes symptoms until significant damage has occurred.

diagnoses: Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with ITP)
Infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C leading to Cryoglobulinemia)
Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) related to Hypertension or Diabetes
Connective tissue diseases (e.g., mixed connective tissue disease)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Drug Reactions (e.g., Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Hepatitis B or C associated arthritis
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
